description.narrative: Strengthened capacities of governance institutions responsible for accountability, justice and participation at all levels
capital of a political entity
Other General Services - support to civil society

1. # of people accessing legal aid and ADR services 2. # of oversight institutions capacity built on Public Finance Accountability 3. # of fora on citizen engagement and social audit conducted; 4. Framework for consistent follow-up on implementation of 2010 Universal Peer Review (UPR) established 5. Gender Policy strategic plan formulated and implementation on commenced 6. comment.narrative: 1. 463 accessing services from Regional Legal Aid Service Centre: 2. limited capacity to undertake public financial management 3. Fora on citizen engagement and social audit conducted on adhoc basis; 4. Limited implementation of 2010 UPR recommendations 5. No strategic framework for Gender 6. No updated Policy and Legal Framework for PLHIV AIDS.

1. Support implementation of Ministry of Justice Strategic Plan 2. Conduct mobile legal aid clinics in two regions 3. Decentralize African Gender Development Index activities in all regions 4. Support to IEC on Electoral processes

1. An operations manual was developed for State Counsel, Legal Clerks and Support Staff of the Ministry of Justice. The manual provides clear guidelines on the designation and roles of staff of the Ministry to ensure effectiveness and efficiency in the operationalization of the Ministry’s strategic plan. 2. Two mobile legal aid clinics held reaching 1058 people, 619 female and 439 male 3. African Gender Development Index (AGDI) database was decentralized to all regions and gender focal points trained on system use 4. The Independent Electoral Commission was website updated and accessible for the transparent and free flow of information. Nation wide civic and voter education targeting first time voters and women were conducted, whilst capacities of polling staff for 1422 polling centers were strengthened. The establishment of the situation room together with training of domestic observers and conflict monitors through support to the CSO Coalition on Elections lent credibility to the electoral results. Media houses were trained also on responsible journalism and effective elections reporting.

1. Institutional support to Ministry of Justice 2. Support to the training of community paralegal in Lower River Region 3. Support to countrywide mobile aid clinics 4.Provide support to preparatory activities on transitional justice mechanisms 5. Support to the African Gender Development Index (AGDI) project 5. Support to The Gambia's participation to CSW

provider-org.narrative: UNDP AS ADMINISTRATIVE AGENT FOR A JOINT PROGRAMME PASS THROUGH ARRANGEMENT
UNDP AS ADMINISTRATIVE AGENT FOR A JOINT PROGRAMME PASS THROUGH ARRANGEMENT

comment.narrative: 1. A Low Emission Climate Resilience Development Strategy (LECRDS) formulated. 2. Support provided to MEA, (UNCBD, UNCCD, UNFCCC) 3. A National Policy on Strategic Environment Assessment (SEA) 4. DRR Project Formulated ion 5. RDMCs and other stakeholders trained on the International and National frameworks (NDMA Institutional Frameworks and Sendai Frameworks respectively) 6. 1 IUNVs - DRR & CCA Specialist recruited 7. Assessment of MFPs undertaken 8. solar system for productive uses for women empowerment (Mbollo) installed in an identified community

1. Background paper (1) on LECRDS finalized and is being used to inform the main strategy 2. Gambian delegation (3) supported to participate in UNFCCC COP21 in Morocco & is influencing attitudes to climate change as well as enhancing Resource Mobilization 3. SEA national policy for Gambia formulated and serves to eradicate the environmental consequences of proposed policies, plans/programme initiatives in order to ensure that they are fully included and appropriately addressed at the earliest appropriate time of decision-making at par with economic and social considerations . 4. 350 RDMC members & community representatives trained on NDMA institutional and Sendai Frameworks and are using the knowledge and skills gained to address threats such as waterway blockages, indiscriminate waste disposal, flashfloods as national emergency issues. Members are better prepared to minimize disasters and improved detection, assessment, monitoring and early warning systems for enhanced resistance building, 5. One UNV Specialist for DRR & CCA recruited 6.Solat PV equipment procured for productive uses for women empowerment and building site identified for construction and installation to commence in 2017

1. To build/construct Solar PV shelter and install solar equipment for productive uses for women empowerment 2. To develop a LECRDS for the Gambia 3. To support the participation of Gambian delegation to the UNFCCC COp22

description.narrative: Sustainable livelihoods security enhanced for the disadvantaged groups through the promotion of income diversification opportunities and better management of environmental resources

1: Procurement of Equipment (Photoshop software, external drives) 2: Conduct a National Empretec Day and Forum and the Operationalization and management of EMPRETEC Forum regionally 3: Support the new trainees with a staff during the National Trade Fair 4: Organize publicity sensitization campaigns through Newspapers, TV, T-shirts, Billboards and Radios 5: Produce a document on all EMPRETEC activity 6: Interview and selection process for Entrepreneurs Country wide 7: Conduct Entrepreneurship Training Workshop (Banjul/KMC, Janjangburreh, Basse, Mansakonko, Kerewan, Brikama 8: Provide BUSINESS DEVELOMENT SERVICES to newly establish businesses trained under the project 9: Hire a consultant to Conduct a Project Evaluation 10: Capacity building through training of Employment Unit staff and key partners by the UNV Employment Specialist (In-House Training) 11: Training and awareness creation on Labour & Trade Union Bill

description.narrative: Support and promote community based natural resources management initiatives such as ecotourism.
capital of a political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration
1. # of community based natural resource management initiative (CBNRM) operationalized; 2. # of trained committee member managing natural resources;

comment.narrative: 1. No initiative on Community Based Natural Resource Management Initiative operationalization; 2. No committee members trained on natural resource management;

1. Capacities of women in community forest communities enhanced in collection, preservation and processing techniques of forest fruits and nuts; Support provided for the designation process of forestland management and ownership from state own to community ownership and management. 2. Assessment of tree nursery and seedling multiplication activity at Jarume Koto conducted

1. About 95 Community Forest Committee (CFC) members involving 70 women & 25 men were trained in collection, preservation and processing techniques of forest fruits & nuts. Women are now engaged in forest fruit value addition activities as a source of additional income and for food security 2. 30 Forest Communities, representing 90 members (30 women & 60 men) were trained in the designation process of forestland management and ownership from state own to community ownership & Management. Communities can now lead and manage the process of designating community forest ownership and management with very little help from the public sector. The concept is now widespread in many other regions and is contributing to better management of the forestland, thus preventing/reversing the annual loss of 10,000 ha of forest land. 3. An assessment was done on the tree nursery and seedling multiplication activity in Jarume Koto. The results were impressive and communities are now engaged in raising seedlings for farm boundary planting, selling surplus to needy institutions and individuals as a source of income, environmental protection and for food security.
N/A for the period January to September 2017
N/A for the period January to September 2017

comment.narrative: 1. Conduct mid-term evaluation of the project. 2. Procure communication and visibility materials 3. Conduct ponder and anti-salt facility management training and production of associated guidelines for Tendaba Illiasa and Dasilameh 5. Construct coastal protection measures al Kololi/Tangi bridge 6. Restoration of 375ha in study-identified areas along the bintang bolon and associated pre-restoration activities and post restoration monitoring 7. Provide livelihoods support to fifteen communities 8. Provide 35 Fiberglas canoes and accessories to five women group 9. Partner with NARI to build and introduce improved rice varieties in Tendaba 10. Develop and exit strategy through direct engagement of partners and project beneficiaries

Zero within government sector minimal and sporadic in tourist sector

Uneconomic degraded rice production and no fish ranching production in target communities

Rice and fish production represent economic sustainable livelihood activity for community members in 20 wards in the Lower and Central Valleys 1500 rice growers and 300 horticulture producers diversity income

Design for an integrated rice salt and fish farming scheme produced for Dasilami and Illiasa communities working at ward level is not practical Five communities received support in horticulture with combined beneficiaries of 671 men and female that is expected to increase

title.narrative: Electoral Support to The Gambia 2016 to 2018

description.narrative: Provide support for improving the legal framework for elections through an inclusive process, whilst enhancing the participation of youth and women.

title.narrative: Support to the Gambia Electoral Cycle

description.narrative: Electoral institutions enabled to perform core functions for improved accountability, participation and representation, including for peaceful transition
capital of a political entity
Elections - elections

1. Enhanced public image/perception of the IEC 2. Increased capacity of IEC staff on voter register management; and records and data management system functional 3. Improved stakeholders trust and collaboration as reflected in consensus on legal and policy frameworks 4. Strategic Plan for NCCE developed and adopted with a view to expanding its role beyond elections’ 5. Barriers identified and gender-sensitive electoral legal and regulatory framework enacted by the National Assembly and adopted by political parties

comment.narrative: 1. Low public image/perception of the IEC 2. No centralised and effective data and record management system 3. Non-existence of Forum for broad stakeholder consultations 4. No Strategic Plan for the NCCE 5. No articulated strategy on gender and elections

Develop and implement operational plan and internal business policies and process Training of IEC staff on voter registration. Promote public awareness on gender equality and women’s empowerment through community conversation (grass-root efforts) and media outputs and campaigns and outdoor activities (drama, dance and music) as part of voter and civic education Support training of Media practitioners, and forums and networks to report on election and democracy issues, such as gender, inclusive participation, legal reform, media freedom, elections-related conflict management and democratic values.

The Independent Electoral Commission website updated and accessible for the transparent and free flow of information. Nation wide civic and voter education targeting first time voters and women were conducted, whilst capacities of polling staff for 1422 polling centers were strengthened. The establishment of the situation room together with training of domestic observers and conflict monitors through support to the CSO Coalition on Elections lent credibility to the electoral results. Media houses were trained also on responsible journalism and effective elections reporting.
Support the conduct of National Assembly Elections

title.narrative: Support to Transitional Justice in Gambia

description.narrative: support to development of SSR policy and implementation framework; through facilitation of national consultation, indepth assessment and analysis of capacity and needs and formulation of policy and regulatory framework
capital of a political entity
Anti corruption
1. # of national dialogue fora undertaken 2. National SSR strategy in existence (Yes/No) 3. Existence of coordination framework (yes/No)

comment.narrative: 1. Absence of a dialogue with population and key stakeholders on SSR 2. Absence of national SSR strategy 3. Absence of coordination mechanism for SSR

Team of three experts operational in June 2017 Assessment of the entire security sector conducted (taking gender and human rights dimension and conflict-sensitivities into account At least 5 meetings platform of dialogue with stakeholders and of national consultations (men and women, all regions) resulting in clear recommendations Population (men and women, all regions and ethnic groups) and key stakeholders are consulted on security needs and objectives for SSR – common understanding/vision built Technical Committee for SSR support operational - At least 12 meetings held - a detailed mapping of all interventions in security sector is available - Existence of national SSR strategy

capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: supporting the establishment of transitional justice mechanism

description.narrative: Human rights affairs

1. A comprehensive nationally owned, inclusive, gender-sensitive and victim-centered Strategy of high quality on TJ is available for implementation (yes/no) 2. Coordination framework for transitional justice outlined/transitional justice strategy outlined ( yes/no) 3. # of consultation undertaken; # of recommendations from consultations 4. Establishment of Paris Principle compliant NHRI ( yes/no)

comment.narrative:
1. Absence of strategy 2. Uncoordinated initiatives from various state institutions and civil society in a piece meal approach 3. Absence of consultation and dialogue regarding the type of TJ needed 4. Insufficient national capacities on TJ
Absence of National Assembly Act establishing the National Human Rights Commission (NHRC) compliant with the Paris Principles - Absence of a strategic plan to guide the National Human Rights Commission (NHRC)

High quality Strategy Document drafted and validated The Gambia is equipped with a National Assembly Act compliant with the Paris Principles, that establishes a National Human Rights Commission (NHRC) The National Human Rights Commission (NHRC) is equipped with a strategic plan to start operating
